citation.article-title: Acrocarpospora gen. nov., a new genus of the order Actinomycetales.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Acrocarpospora gen. nov.

Acrocarpospora (A.cro.car.po.spo'ra. Gr. adj. Akros pointed, sharp, highest; Gr. n. karpos fruit, harvest; Gr. fem. n. spora a seed; M.L. fem. n. Acrocarpospora an organism forming spores like fruits on the terminal mycelium)
Cells are Gram-positive and non-acid-fast and organisms form branching hyphae.
Non-fragmentary substrate mycelia are present.
Spherical and club-shaped structures are borne on the tips of the aerial mycelium.
These structures contain coiled spore chains.
Spores are oval or short rod-like (0.6-0.8x0.7-1.0 Œºm) with a smooth surface and nonmotile.
Strictly aerobic.
Good growth occurs between 20 and 30¬∞C.
The organism shows good growth on oatmeal agar.
In general, the vegetative mycelia are pale yellow and aerial hyphae are white.
Cell walls contain glutamic acid, alanine and meso-diaminopimelic acid.
Wall chemotype is III (Lechevalier & Lechevalier, 1970) and the peptidoglycan type is presumed to be A1ùõæ (Schleifer & Kandler, 1972).
Madurose, glucose and galactose are detected in whole-cell sugars.
Major cellular fatty acids are iso-C16:0, 10-methyl C17:0, C17:1 and C17:0.
The G+C content of DNA is 68.69 mol%.
The major menaquinones are MK-9(H4) and MK-9(H2) and small amounts ofMK-9(H6) are present.
Phosphatidylethanolamine is present as a diagnostic phospholipid.
Mycolic acids are absent.
The acyl type of cell-wall polysaccharide is acetyl.
The type species is Acrocarpospora pleiomorpha.
